F01_1token_response_time.reason: Thermal hazards require immediate response: reduce fire, open vent, redirect flow

F02_first_order_markov_sufficient.reason: Thermal state visible now; no need to remember previous temperatures

F03_categorical_not_numeric.reason: Pre-instrument distillation uses sensory categories: hot/warm/cool, clear/cloudy

F04_high_dimensional_incompatibility.reason: Hundreds of aromatic compounds with complex cross-reactivity and co-occurrence rules

F05_strong_transitivity.reason: Compatible materials share physical properties (volatility, polarity) that propagate

F06_hazard_asymmetry.reason: Phase transitions are asymmetric: heating past boil is dangerous, cooling past boil is safe

F07_absorbing_stabilization_state.reason: Cooling/condensation IS the natural attractor — system returns to equilibrium via cooling

F08_lane_oscillation.reason: Natural heating/monitoring oscillation: apply heat (QO), check result (CHSH), adjust

F09_energy_medial_concentration.reason: Setup (prepare apparatus) -> Heat (distill) -> Close (collect/seal) matches medial energy

F10_recovery_unconditionally_free.reason: Recovery from a near-boilover or contamination has many valid strategies depending on setup

F11_universal_grammar.reason: Same control vocabulary applies to all materials/runs (same apparatus, same operations)

F12_phase_ordering_dominant_hazard.reason: Phase ordering is THE central challenge: liquid/vapor boundary management

F13_convergent_monostate.reason: Distillation naturally converges to steady-state reflux as the operational target

F14_exactly_5_hazard_classes.reason: Phase, composition, containment, rate, energy = 5 natural failure families in distillation

F15_closed_loop_not_batch.reason: Pelican reflux IS a closed-loop circulatory system by definition

F16_line_boundary_memory_reset.reason: Each fraction/operation starts fresh from current apparatus state, not from history

F17_link_monitoring_phase.reason: Constant monitoring between interventions: watch the still, check the drip, smell the output

F18_e_recovery_dominance.reason: Cooling IS the primary recovery in distillation: reduce heat, let system equilibrate

F19_folio_vocabulary_uniqueness.reason: Different distillation runs process different materials with distinct properties

F20_design_asymmetry.reason: Physics of failure is universal (same for all materials) but recovery depends on what you are distilling

F01_1token_response_time.reason: Fermentation operates on hour/day timescale; no immediate hazard response needed

F02_first_order_markov_sufficient.reason: Fermentation progress depends on cumulative biological history

F03_categorical_not_numeric.reason: Some categorical (taste, color) but also quantitative (time, volume)

F04_high_dimensional_incompatibility.reason: Simple: few ingredients (grain, water, yeast), low-dimensional parameter space

F05_strong_transitivity.reason: Fermentation compatibility is not transitive (yeast A+sugar does not predict yeast B+sugar)

F07_absorbing_stabilization_state.reason: Fermentation has completion (all sugar consumed) as attractor but this is terminal, not recovery

F08_lane_oscillation.reason: No rapid oscillation in fermentation; it is passive waiting

F09_energy_medial_concentration.reason: Energy is not a major concept in fermentation (it is biological, not thermal)

F10_recovery_unconditionally_free.reason: Fermentation recovery is limited (contaminated batch is usually lost)

F11_universal_grammar.reason: Different ferments require very different procedures (wine vs beer vs vinegar)

F12_phase_ordering_dominant_hazard.reason: Fermentation has no phase ordering (single liquid phase throughout)

F13_convergent_monostate.reason: Fermentation also converges to completion (all sugar consumed)

F14_exactly_5_hazard_classes.reason: Fermentation has ~2 failure modes (contamination, stuck fermentation), not 5

F15_closed_loop_not_batch.reason: Fermentation is batch (start to finish, no circulation)

F16_line_boundary_memory_reset.reason: Fermentation is continuous; no memory resets between stages

F17_link_monitoring_phase.reason: Some monitoring (check gravity, taste, smell) but infrequent (daily not continuous)

F19_folio_vocabulary_uniqueness.reason: Different ferments use different ingredients but vocabulary is much smaller

F20_design_asymmetry.reason: Fermentation failure and recovery are both material-dependent, not asymmetric

F01_1token_response_time.reason: Furnace has fast hazards (crack, spill) but response is physical, not categorical

F02_first_order_markov_sufficient.reason: Current metal state is somewhat visible but thermal history matters for annealing

F03_categorical_not_numeric.reason: Requires numeric: weight of ore, assay results, temperature estimation

F04_high_dimensional_incompatibility.reason: Moderate: many alloy compositions but compatibility is lower-dimensional

F05_strong_transitivity.reason: Alloy compatibility is partially transitive (similar melting points cluster)

F06_hazard_asymmetry.reason: Some asymmetry (heating iron is different from cooling) but less pronounced

F07_absorbing_stabilization_state.reason: Cooling is important in metallurgy but not a dominant recovery mechanism in the same way

F08_lane_oscillation.reason: Metallurgy has heating but no systematic oscillation with monitoring

F09_energy_medial_concentration.reason: Metallurgy also has: prepare furnace -> heat -> remove product. Similar medial pattern

F10_recovery_unconditionally_free.reason: Some recovery flexibility in metallurgy but options are more constrained by material

F11_universal_grammar.reason: Partially universal (furnace operations shared) but metals require specialized operations

F12_phase_ordering_dominant_hazard.reason: Phase matters (solid/liquid/gas) but not as dominant as in distillation

F13_convergent_monostate.reason: Metal working has target states but they vary (different alloys, different products)

F14_exactly_5_hazard_classes.reason: Metallurgy has several failure modes but different classes (crack, wrong alloy, oxidation)

F15_closed_loop_not_batch.reason: Metallurgy is batch processing (heat, transform, cool, done)

F16_line_boundary_memory_reset.reason: Each heating cycle somewhat independent but thermal history affects metal

F17_link_monitoring_phase.reason: Metallurgy has less monitoring between actions (fire-and-wait pattern)

F18_e_recovery_dominance.reason: Metallurgy recovery is not cooling-dominated; re-heating is equally common

F19_folio_vocabulary_uniqueness.reason: Different ores have different properties but the vocabulary is smaller

F20_design_asymmetry.reason: Both hazards and recovery vary by metal type; not clearly asymmetric

F01_1token_response_time.reason: Glass cracking/burning requires fast response but less categorical decision space

F02_first_order_markov_sufficient.reason: Current viscosity visible but thermal history affects stress accumulation

F03_categorical_not_numeric.reason: Requires numeric: temperature estimation, thickness, timing

F04_high_dimensional_incompatibility.reason: Low-dimensional: few components (silica, soda, lime), simple compatibility

F05_strong_transitivity.reason: Glass compatibility is not strongly transitive

F06_hazard_asymmetry.reason: Some asymmetry in heating/cooling glass but thermal shock is more symmetric

F07_absorbing_stabilization_state.reason: Glass has no absorbing state — you keep heating or it cools and freezes (different logic)

F08_lane_oscillation.reason: Glass working is continuous heating, not oscillatory

F09_energy_medial_concentration.reason: Glass: prepare tools -> heat glass -> shape/finish. Similar medial pattern

F10_recovery_unconditionally_free.reason: Glass recovery is very limited — once cracked or mis-shaped, material is lost

F11_universal_grammar.reason: Different glass types require different techniques (blowing vs fusing vs annealing)

F12_phase_ordering_dominant_hazard.reason: Viscous-liquid transition matters but it is gradual, not a sharp ordering problem

F13_convergent_monostate.reason: Annealing converges to cooled state, but working has many target shapes

F14_exactly_5_hazard_classes.reason: Glass has ~2-3 failure modes (thermal shock, wrong shape, crystallization)

F15_closed_loop_not_batch.reason: Glass annealing involves controlled cooling but not a circulatory loop

F16_line_boundary_memory_reset.reason: Glass state carries forward continuously; no clean resets

F17_link_monitoring_phase.reason: Glass working is continuous action, not monitor-then-act

F18_e_recovery_dominance.reason: Glass recovery is not cooling-dominated (re-heating broken piece is standard)

F19_folio_vocabulary_uniqueness.reason: Glass recipes are relatively uniform; limited vocabulary variation

F20_design_asymmetry.reason: Both failure modes and recovery are glass-type dependent

F01_1token_response_time.reason: No continuous hazard; compounding is step-by-step at room temperature

F02_first_order_markov_sufficient.reason: Recipe progress requires tracking what has been added (cumulative state)

F03_categorical_not_numeric.reason: Requires precise quantities: weights, measures, proportions are central

F04_high_dimensional_incompatibility.reason: Moderate: drug interactions exist but typical formulary has <100 ingredients

F05_strong_transitivity.reason: Drug interactions are famously non-transitive (A+B safe, B+C safe, A+C toxic)

F06_hazard_asymmetry.reason: Compounding order sometimes matters but this is recipe, not hazard

F07_absorbing_stabilization_state.reason: No absorbing state in compounding; each step is discrete

F08_lane_oscillation.reason: No oscillation in sequential recipe execution

F09_energy_medial_concentration.reason: No thermal energy phase in compounding

F10_recovery_unconditionally_free.reason: Wrong proportion in pharmacy is typically not recoverable

F11_universal_grammar.reason: Each recipe is unique; no universal grammar of compounding

F13_convergent_monostate.reason: Each recipe has its own endpoint; no universal convergent state

F14_exactly_5_hazard_classes.reason: Pharmacy has ~2 failure modes (wrong amount, wrong ingredient)

F15_closed_loop_not_batch.reason: Compounding is linear sequential, not circulatory

F16_line_boundary_memory_reset.reason: Each step depends on what was added before; no resets

F19_folio_vocabulary_uniqueness.reason: Different medicines use different ingredients; moderate vocabulary

F20_design_asymmetry.reason: Both errors and corrections are recipe-specific

F01_1token_response_time.reason: No physical process requiring immediate response

F02_first_order_markov_sufficient.reason: Calendar position requires knowing date (cumulative time)

F03_categorical_not_numeric.reason: Calendar uses categorical (which day/planet) but also counts (which hour)

F05_strong_transitivity.reason: No transitivity concept applies to calendar/ritual

F11_universal_grammar.reason: Calendar has universal structure (months, hours) but content varies by tradition

F16_line_boundary_memory_reset.reason: Calendar is continuous; no memory resets

F01_1token_response_time.reason: Dyeing hazards are slow (color wrong, mordant failure); no immediate gate needed

F02_first_order_markov_sufficient.reason: Current dye state partially visible but mordant history matters

F03_categorical_not_numeric.reason: Some categorical (color matching) but also quantitative (dye amounts, timing)

F04_high_dimensional_incompatibility.reason: Low-dimensional: limited dye/mordant combinations, mostly independent

F06_hazard_asymmetry.reason: Dyeing order matters (mordant before dye) but not in a hazard sense

F07_absorbing_stabilization_state.reason: Rinse/cool is a recovery step but not a dominant attractor (17% not 55%)

F08_lane_oscillation.reason: No rapid heating/monitoring oscillation in dyeing

F09_energy_medial_concentration.reason: Heat bath in middle of dye process, but not as pronounced as distillation

F10_recovery_unconditionally_free.reason: Some recovery options in dyeing (re-dye, re-mordant) but limited

F11_universal_grammar.reason: Different dyes require different procedures (mordant type, temperature, timing)

F12_phase_ordering_dominant_hazard.reason: No significant phase ordering hazard in dyeing

F13_convergent_monostate.reason: Dyeing converges to "done" (color achieved) but this is binary, not a state

F14_exactly_5_hazard_classes.reason: Dyeing has ~2 failure modes (wrong color, poor fixation)

F15_closed_loop_not_batch.reason: Vat dyeing involves immersion/removal cycles but not a true closed loop

F16_line_boundary_memory_reset.reason: Rinse between dye baths provides partial reset

F17_link_monitoring_phase.reason: Some monitoring (check color) but less frequent than distillation

F18_e_recovery_dominance.reason: Recovery in dyeing is not cooling-dominated

F19_folio_vocabulary_uniqueness.reason: Different dyes have different properties but limited vocabulary

F01_1token_response_time.reason: Seasonal timescale; no sub-minute hazard response

F02_first_order_markov_sufficient.reason: Crop state depends on season history; not first-order

F03_categorical_not_numeric.reason: Requires numeric: planting dates, water amounts, field dimensions

F04_high_dimensional_incompatibility.reason: Low-dimensional: crop rotation rules are simple (3-4 categories)

F05_strong_transitivity.reason: Crop rotation compatibility is not strongly transitive

F06_hazard_asymmetry.reason: No directional hazard concept in farming

F07_absorbing_stabilization_state.reason: No absorbing state in seasonal agriculture

F10_recovery_unconditionally_free.reason: Crop failure recovery is seasonal; not a within-process concept

F11_universal_grammar.reason: Crops are highly variable; no universal agricultural grammar

F13_convergent_monostate.reason: Harvest is a convergent endpoint but it is annual, not per-run

F14_exactly_5_hazard_classes.reason: Agriculture has failures but they are not within-process hazards

F15_closed_loop_not_batch.reason: Agriculture is seasonal linear, not circulatory

F19_folio_vocabulary_uniqueness.reason: Limited crop vocabulary; not per-field unique

F20_design_asymmetry.reason: Both failure and recovery are crop/season dependent

Alloy compatibility is partially transitive (similar melting points cluster)
Some asymmetry (heating iron is different from cooling) but less pronounced
Cooling is important in metallurgy but not a dominant recovery mechanism in the same way

Some recovery flexibility in metallurgy but options are more constrained by material
Partially universal (furnace operations shared) but metals require specialized operations
Phase matters (solid/liquid/gas) but not as dominant as in distillation
Metal working has target states but they vary (different alloys, different products)
Metallurgy has several failure modes but different classes (crack, wrong alloy, oxidation)
Each heating cycle somewhat independent but thermal history affects metal

explanation: Distillation scores 100.0%. Best alternative (METALLURGY) scores 37.5%. Exclusion gap: 62.5%. Killer features: 18/20. All alternatives below 50% with gap >= 30%. The structural fingerprint is uniquely compatible with thermal circulatory distillation.
